journal-meta.journal-title: The American Journal of Sports Medicine

title-group.article-title: Repair of Peripheral Vertical Meniscus Lesions in Porcine Menisci
title-group.subtitle: In Vitro Biomechanical Testing of 3 Different Meniscus Repair Devices

article-meta.aff: *Division of Sports Medicine, Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, University of Louisville, Louisville, Kentucky
Investigation performed at the Division of Sports Medicine, Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, University of Louisville, Louisville, Kentucky

author-notes.corresp: †John Nyland, EdD, DPT, Division of Sports Medicine, Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, University of Louisville, 550 South Jackson Street, 1st Floor ACB, Louisville, KY 40202 (e-mail: john.nyland@louisville.edu).

permissions.copyright-holder: American Orthopaedic Society for Sports Medicine

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: All-inside meniscus repair eliminates the need for an extra incision and decreases neurovascular injury risk. Biomechanical testing can help delineate the efficacy of all-inside device use.

sec.title: Hypothesis:
sec.p: There would be no group differences between 4 peripheral meniscus repair techniques and 3 different devices tested.

sec.title: Study Design:
sec.p: Controlled laboratory study.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: Equivalent-sized menisci with attached tibiae were randomly assigned to 1 of 4 test groups (8 specimens each), as follows: group 1, Fast-Fix using No. 0 braided polyester suture; group 2, inside-out repair using 2-0 braided polyester suture; group 3, Sequent using No. 0 ultra–high molecular weight polyethylene (UHMWPE) suture in a continuous “N” configuration; and group 4, Sequent using No. 0 UHMWPE suture in an interrupted configuration. After placement in a clamp, specimens underwent preconditioning from 5 to 20 N for 10 cycles (0.1 Hz), 500 submaximal loading cycles from 5 to 20 N (0.5 Hz), and load-to-failure testing at 12.5 mm/s. A 30-second pause after 10 preconditioning cycles and after 10, 100, and 500 submaximal loading cycles enabled digital photographs to be taken for gapping measurements. Failure mode was recorded.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Specimens in group 3 withstood greater failure loads than did those in groups 1 and 4 (P ≤ .027), and group 3 specimens were stiffer than those in groups 2 and 4 (P ≤ .048). Displacement during submaximal loading and load-to-failure testing did not differ between groups. Groups 1, 3, and 4 each gapped less than group 2 during submaximal cyclic loading (P ≤ .05). Groups 1 and 2 failed primarily by suture breakage (P < .0001), while groups 3 and 4 failed primarily by the suture pulling free from an implant (P < .0001).

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: Sequent using No. 0 UHMWPE suture in a continuous “N” configuration displayed superior load at failure compared with repairs using Fast-Fix with No. 0 braided polyester suture and displayed greater stiffness and less gapping than inside-out repair using 2-0 braided polyester suture. The suture pulling free from an implant was the primary failure mode for Sequent using No. 0 UHMWPE suture regardless of whether a continuous “N” or an interrupted configuration was used. Study groups that used No. 0 UHMWPE sutures (groups 3 and 4) had more specimens fail by the suture pulling free from an implant. Compared with the weaker braided polyester suture in the inside-out and Fast-Fix groups, the No. 0 UHMWPE suture used in the Sequent groups likely influenced study results, as this suture has stronger material properties. However, the continuous “N” configuration likely also improved the performance of the Sequent with No. 0 UHMWPE suture, as failure load was significantly less with an interrupted configuration.

sec.title: Clinical Relevance:
sec.p: All-inside meniscus repair with continuous suture function may translate into improved patient outcomes.

body.p: An improved understanding of knee biomechanics has emphasized the need for meniscus preservation.17,19 Meniscus repair has progressed over the past 25 years from open techniques to arthroscopically assisted inside-out and outside-in techniques.23,28,30,33 Further progression to completely arthroscopic techniques using all-inside meniscus repair devices has eliminated the need for an additional surgical incision and reduced the risk of neurovascular injury.

The recent introduction of ultra–high molecular weight polyethylene (UHMWPE) sutures in devices such as the Ultra Fast-Fix (Smith & Nephew, Andover, Massachusetts) and Meniscal Cinch (Arthrex, Naples, Florida) have further improved the biomechanical fixation characteristics of all-inside meniscus repair devices. Barber et al5 reported that meniscus repair using UHMWPE sutures such as the 2-0 Ultrabraid (Smith & Nephew), 2-0 FiberWire (Arthrex), and 2-0 Orthocord (DePuy Mitek, Raynham, Massachusetts) provided greater load-to-failure strength than meniscus repair techniques that use conventional sutures. The Sequent (ConMed Linvatec, Largo, Florida) represents a new all-inside meniscus repair device that uses No. 0 UHMWPE suture material.4 Sequent was designed to provide continuous suture stitch linkages between polyether ether ketone (PEEK) implants. Manufacturer recommendations, however, suggest that after successful insertion of the first 2 implants if the subsequent implant does not successfully deploy, the suture can be cut and tied without compromising repair integrity. The purpose of this biomechanical study of an in vitro porcine model was to compare 4 different peripheral vertical meniscus repair techniques of 3 different devices using a cyclic loading test protocol. The study hypothesis was that there would be no differences between the comparison groups.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: A biomechanical study of an in vitro porcine model was performed to compare 4 different peripheral meniscus repair techniques. Based on pilot test data, an a priori statistical power analysis suggested that to identify a 1.0-mm cyclic displacement difference between groups with common standard deviations of 0.8 mm, 8 specimens per group would be needed to have a statistical power of 80% (β = .20) at an α level of P = .05. A 1-mm measurement threshold was selected because it provided a clinically meaningful unit representative of a small meniscus repair gap.2,18,20 Tibiae with attached lateral menisci and joint capsules were harvested from adult hogs, fresh frozen, and stored for 48 hours at −20°C. After thawing for 12 hours, equivalent-sized lateral porcine menisci with attached tibiae were randomly assigned to 4 test groups (8 specimens per group).

sec.title: Creation and Repair of Meniscus Lesion
sec.p: With use of a metric ruler, markings were made on each specimen to indicate lesion locations and suture needle entry points for meniscus repair. A scalpel was used to create standardized, longitudinal peripheral vertical lesions across the entire length of each meniscus 4 mm from the periphery. The suture needle depth-limiting sheath was cut to 2 cm. Each group was repaired using the same suture needle entry point locations and order. The first meniscus repair device used was determined at random by drawing a number from a hat. After this, menisci were repaired and tested in a numerical group sequence to control for potential order effects. The 4 groups were as follows: group 1, conventional all-inside meniscus repair using 2 Fast-Fix meniscus repair devices with 2 vertical No. 0 braided polyester sutures placed 4 mm apart across the lesion (4 implants, 4 strands total); group 2, two vertical inside-out 2-0 braided polyester sutures placed 4 mm apart across the lesion (4 strands); group 3, Sequent all-inside meniscus repair using No. 0 UHMWPE suture in an “N” configuration with the 2 vertical limbs placed 4 mm apart across the lesion (4 implants, 5 strands total) (Figure 1); and group 4, Sequent all-inside meniscus repair using No. 0 UHMWPE suture in an interrupted configuration with 2 suture rows placed 4 mm apart across the lesion (4 implants, 4 strands total). This group represented Sequent use after successful insertion of the first 2 implants with subsequent deployment failure of the next implant.

caption.p: An oil-based marker identified standard meniscus lesions and suture needle entry points (X) in each study group: group 1, Fast-Fix using No. 0 braided polyester suture; group 2, inside-out repair using 2-0 braided polyester suture; group 3, Sequent using No. 0 ultra–high molecular weight polyethylene (UHMWPE) suture in a continuous “N” configuration; and group 4, Sequent using No. 0 UHMWPE suture in an interrupted configuration. The first entry point (A) was 8 mm from the left side of the lesion, 2 mm above the edge. The second entry point (B) was 8 mm from the left side of the lesion, 2 mm below the edge. The third entry point (C) was 8 mm from the right side of the lesion, 2 mm above the edge. The final entry point (D) was 8 mm from the right side of the lesion, 2 mm below the edge. Solid lines = visible sutures; dotted lines = sutures embedded in meniscus.

sec.title: Biomechanical Testing
sec.p:
After repair, the meniscus was carefully dissected from the tibia and placed in a custom clamp as described in previous studies (Figure 2).3,8,15,34-36 During testing, only the repair devices provided fixation across the meniscus lesion. Specimens underwent the following biomechanical test protocol:
Repaired specimens were secured in the clamp, 2 supplemental K-wires provided secondary fixation, and the clamp was then placed in a servohydraulic device (MTS 858, MTS Systems, Eden Prairie, Minnesota).
A 5-N (1.1-lb) tensile load was applied.
Constructs were preconditioned for 10 cycles at 0.1 Hz from 5 to 20 N to remove system slack.
Constructs underwent 500 submaximal loading cycles at 0.5 Hz from 5 to 20 N.
Load-to-failure testing was performed at 12.5 mm/s.

caption.p: Clamp with supplemental K-wires used to secure the peripheral portion of the repaired meniscus during biomechanical testing.

sec.p: This biomechanical test protocol has been previously described in the literature to evaluate meniscus repair devices.15,35 The loads were applied in line with the axis of the implants to simulate a worst-case scenario. The 12.5-mm/s displacement rate is considered representative of in vivo loading forces.8,35,36 Cyclic testing was included to simulate in vivo loading forces experienced during the early postsurgery period.21,22,29 The servohydraulic device was preprogrammed to allow for a 30-second pause after the 10 preconditioning cycles and after 10, 100, and 500 submaximal loading cycles. This provided sufficient time for a standardized digital photograph to be taken. This was later used for measurement determination of meniscus repair gapping. Failure mode was recorded by a trained investigator (R.B.) other than the surgeon.

sec.title: Gapping Measurements
sec.p: A camera (FinePix S7000, Fuji, Tokyo, Japan) positioned on a tripod with the lens aligned 76.2 cm from the clamped specimen was used to collect digital photographs after the application of a 5-N load, after 10 preconditioning cycles and after 10, 100, and 500 submaximal loading cycles. A metric ruler with 1-mm increments was positioned parallel to the clamp to provide a gap measurement scale. Repair gapping was measured from printed digital photographs using an electronic caliper (model 47257, Cen-Tech, Camarillo, California) in the following manner: measurement 1 was the greatest distance between the meniscus lesion edges within the suture repair zone, and measurement 2 was 10 mm on the metric ruler. From these 2 measurements, standardized peak gapping was determined by dividing measurement 1 by measurement 2 and then multiplying this value by 10. Two investigators, each blinded to the other’s measurements, recorded peak gap values at each cyclic loading interval. These measurements displayed excellent (intraclass correlation coefficient, 0.90-0.94) reliability. Mean values for these gapping measurements were standardized to mean values for the initial gapping measurement taken before cyclic loading with the specimen clamped and under a 5-N (1.1-lb) tensile load.18

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Kolmogorov-Smirnov tests were used to evaluate data normality for key test variables (failure load, total displacement). Independent variables included displacement over the 500 submaximal loading cycles (mean of the last 10 loading cycles – mean of the initial 10 loading cycles); gapping after the initial 10 preconditioning cycles and after 10, 100, and 500 submaximal loading cycles; load at failure; displacement during load-to-failure testing; and stiffness ([maximum load – initial load]/[maximum displacement – initial displacement along a linear section of the load-displacement curve]). Fisher exact tests were used to determine if group failure modes displayed statistically significant differences. An α level of P < .05 was selected to determine statistical significance. All statistical analyses were performed using SPSS version 20.0 (IBM-SPSS, Armonk, New York) software.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Kolmogorov-Smirnov tests revealed that test variables displayed normal distributions. Therefore, parametric statistical analysis was performed. One-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) (group) and Tukey honestly significant difference post hoc tests were used to evaluate group variable differences in biomechanical testing (Appendix 1, available in the online version of this article at http://ajsm.sagepub.com/supplemental/). Significant group differences were not observed for displacement during submaximal cyclic loading or during load-to-failure testing. Group 3 displayed superior load at failure to group 1 (P = .02) and group 4 (P = .001) (Table 1). Group 2 also displayed superior load at failure to group 4 (P = .027) (Figure 3). Group 3 displayed superior stiffness to group 2 (P = .026) and group 4 (P = .048) (Figure 4).

fn.p: Inside-out repair using 2-0 braided polyester suture (group 2) displayed superior load at failure to Sequent using No. 0 ultra–high molecular weight polyethylene (UHMWPE) suture in an interrupted configuration (group 4) (P = .027).

fn.label: c
fn.p: Sequent using No. 0 UHMWPE suture in a continuous “N” configuration (group 3) displayed superior load at failure to Fast-Fix using No. 0 braided polyester suture (group 1) (P = .02) and to Sequent using No. 0 UHMWPE suture in an interrupted configuration (group 4) (P = .001).

fn.label: d
fn.p: Sequent using No. 0 UHMWPE suture in a continuous “N” configuration (group 3) displayed superior stiffness to inside-out repair using 2-0 braided polyester suture (group 2) (P = .048) and to Sequent using No. 0 UHMWPE suture in an interrupted configuration (group 4) (P = .026).

caption.p: Group load at failure results (mean and 95% confidence interval). Sequent using No. 0 ultra–high molecular weight polyethylene (UHMWPE) suture in a continuous “N” configuration (group 3) displayed superior load at failure to Fast-Fix using No. 0 braided polyester suture (group 1) (†P = .02) and to Sequent using No. 0 UHMWPE suture in an interrupted configuration (group 4) (‡P = .001). The inside-out repair using 2-0 braided polyester suture (group 2) also displayed superior load at failure to Sequent using No. 0 UHMWPE suture in an interrupted configuration (group 4) (ψP = .027).

Group stiffness results (mean and 95% confidence interval). Sequent using No. 0 ultra–high molecular weight polyethylene (UHMWPE) suture in a continuous “N” configuration (group 3) displayed superior stiffness to the inside-out repair using 2-0 braided polyester suture (group 2) (†P = .048) and to Sequent using No. 0 UHMWPE suture in an interrupted configuration (group 4) (‡P = .026).

sec.p: Descriptive statistical analysis of gapping measurements was also performed. A 2-way mixed-model ANOVA (group, interval) and Tukey honestly significant difference post hoc tests were used to evaluate group gapping differences during submaximal cyclic loading (Appendix 2, available online). As expected, standardized gapping increased from the initial 10 preconditioning cycles through 500 submaximal loading cycles across all groups. Of greatest importance is that significant group differences were observed. Group 1 (P = .003), group 3 (P = .05), and group 4 (P = .046) each displayed less gapping under submaximal cyclic loads than group 2 (Table 2). Statistically significant measurement differences in gapping in the absence of statistically significant displacement measurements likely represent the previously mentioned differences between the 2 measurement modes, with displacement not being as specific to the repair site and also being potentially influenced by slight construct slippage. All constructs successfully completed submaximal cyclic loading and load-to-failure testing. Failure modes are reported in Table 3. The study groups that used weaker braided polyester sutures (groups 1 and 2) displayed a greater proportion of specimens that failed by suture breakage (P < .0001). The study groups that used stronger No. 0 UHMWPE sutures (groups 3 and 4) had a greater proportion of specimens that failed by the suture pulling free from an implant (P < .0001).

fn.label: a
fn.p: Values are shown as mean ± standard deviation (95% confidence interval).

fn.label: b
fn.p: Fast-Fix using No. 0 braided polyester suture (P = .003) displayed less gapping at the completion of submaximal cyclic load testing than the inside-out repair using 2-0 braided polyester suture.

fn.label: c
fn.p: Sequent using No. 0 ultra–high molecular weight polyethylene (UHMWPE) suture in a continuous “N” configuration (P = .05) displayed less gapping at the completion of submaximal cyclic load testing than the inside-out repair using 2-0 braided polyester suture.

fn.label: d
fn.p: Sequent using No. 0 UHMWPE suture in an interrupted configuration (P = .048) displayed less gapping at the completion of submaximal cyclic load testing than the inside-out repair using 2-0 braided polyester suture.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Using a biomechanical study of an in vitro porcine model, we found that peripheral vertical meniscus lesions repaired with Sequent using No. 0 UHMWPE suture in a continuous “N” configuration displayed superior load at failure to Fast-Fix using No. 0 braided polyester suture and to Sequent using No. 0 UHMWPE suture in an interrupted configuration. The inside-out group that used 2-0 braided polyester suture also displayed superior load at failure to Sequent using No. 0 UHMWPE suture in an interrupted configuration. Menisci repaired with Sequent using No. 0 UHMWPE suture in a continuous “N” configuration also displayed superior stiffness to the inside-out repair using 2-0 braided polyester suture and to Sequent using No. 0 UHMWPE suture in an interrupted configuration. Regardless of the suture used, each of the 3 all-inside meniscus repair groups (Fast-Fix using No. 0 braided polyester suture, Sequent using No. 0 UHMWPE suture in a continuous “N” configuration, and Sequent using No. 0 UHMWPE suture in an interrupted configuration) displayed less gapping under submaximal cyclic loading conditions than the inside-out repair using 2-0 braided polyester suture.

Inside-out suturing has long been a widely accepted meniscus repair method, with clinical success rates of 75% to 81% based on second-look arthroscopic surgery.10,32 This repair method, however, requires an additional incision for suture retrieval and tying. Therefore, there is a risk of posterior neurovascular injury and capsular tethering when inside-out meniscus repair techniques are used. Although rare, neurovascular complications can occur during meniscus repair,13 and the most serious of these complications have been encountered during suturing.7,11,14,16 Potential advantages related to all-inside meniscus repair techniques include decreased surgical time, reduced neurovascular injury risk, less restricted postoperative range of motion and weightbearing, reduced capsular scarring, and elimination of the need to create an additional incision.1,9,24,31 To be considered as a possible replacement for conventional inside-out suturing, an all-inside meniscus repair device should display comparable failure loads, stiffness, displacement, and gapping characteristics during biomechanical testing.

Early in their development, all-inside devices often displayed inferior biomechanical test performance compared with inside-out suturing with polydioxanone (PDS) or Ethibond (Ethicon, Somerville, New Jersey) sutures.21 Using a cyclic loading protocol, McDermott et al21 reported that bovine meniscus lesions repaired using 2-0 PDS vertical sutures had a mean load at failure of 72.7 N compared with 40.8 N for T-Fix (Acufex, Mansfield, Massachusetts), 34.2 N for Meniscus Arrow (Bionx Implants, Tampere, Finland), and 40.8 N for Meniscal Fastener (Mitek Products, Westwood, Massachusetts). Becker et al6 reported similar results for cadaveric meniscus lesions repaired using horizontal 2-0 Ethibond sutures and T-Fix (62 ± 7.9 N vs 51.4 ± 16.3 N). Other all-inside devices displayed lower ultimate tensile failure loads. As all-inside meniscus repair methods evolved, they began to display improved in vitro biomechanical test results. Using a cyclic loading protocol and bovine meniscus specimens, Zantop et al36 reported that there was no difference in displacement between the Fast-Fix, RapidLoc (DePuy Mitek), and 2-0 Ethibond sutures. They also reported that Fast-Fix displayed greater stiffness and withstood greater load at failure compared with suture repair. Vertical and horizontal Fast-Fix use displayed mean failure loads of 94.1 N and 80.8 N, respectively, while the mean failure load of conventional horizontal sutures was only 50.2 N.36 Barber et al5 reported similar findings using porcine meniscus specimens and load-to-failure testing without a submaximal cyclic loading phase in the test protocol. They reported that vertically placed Fast-Fix devices had a mean load to failure of 70.9 N and that horizontally placed Fast-Fix devices had a mean load to failure of 72.1 N, compared with vertical (80.4 N) and horizontal (55.9 N) meniscus repairs using 2-0 Mersilene (Ethicon) sutures.5 From these findings, they concluded that some second-generation all-inside meniscus repair devices displayed superior biomechanical test findings compared with first-generation devices.5

Using a biomechanical test protocol that included submaximal cyclic loading before load-to-failure testing, Chang et al12 reported that porcine meniscus specimens repaired using 2-0 FiberWire (175.6 N) and 2-0 Ethibond (113.8 N) vertical sutures displayed greater mean loads at failure compared with Fast-Fix (68.0 N) and other all-inside devices including RapidLoc, BioStinger (ConMed Linvatec), and Meniscal Dart (Arthrex). Therefore, even though some second-generation all-inside devices have displayed improved biomechanical test performance, the type of suture that is used significantly influences test results.5,34-36 We found that Sequent using No. 0 UHMWPE suture in a continuous “N” configuration withstood greater load at failure than an inside-out repair using 2-0 braided polyester suture and Fast-Fix using No. 0 braided polyester suture. This superior performance can be explained in part by the No. 0 UHMWPE suture used in Sequent. In contrast, the inside-out and Fast-Fix groups tested in this study relied on weaker 2-0 and No. 0 braided polyester sutures, respectively. We chose to test Fast-Fix with No. 0 braided polyester suture because of its availability and widespread use to directly compare biomechanical performance with the inside-out repair using 2-0 braided polyester suture and to compare these commonly used meniscus repair methods with Sequent using continuous and interrupted No. 0 UHMWPE suture configurations. Barber et al5 have shown that meniscus lesions repaired using No. 0 UHMWPE sutures are stronger than repairs that rely on conventional sutures. Our study supports the findings of Barber et al.5 However, we observed interesting failure mode differences between groups during load-to-failure testing. While suture breakage was the primary failure mode in group 1 (inside-out repair using 2-0 braided polyester suture) and group 2 (Fast-Fix using No. 0 braided polyester suture), in both Sequent groups (groups 3 and 4), the primary failure mode was either the No. 0 UHMWPE suture pulling free from the PEEK implant or the suture-implant complex pulling through the meniscus. Despite its use of a stronger No. 0 UHMWPE suture, Sequent used in an interrupted suture configuration withstood considerably less load at failure than Sequent using No. 0 UHMWPE suture in a continuous “N” configuration. The failure mode suggests that when Sequent with No. 0 UHMWPE suture is used in an interrupted configuration, loads may become more concentrated at the suture-implant interface, leading to failure at comparably lower loads. A key feature of Sequent using No. 0 UHMWPE suture is its capacity to distribute loads across several implants. However, when it is used in an interrupted fashion, this benefit may not occur.

We postulate that the unique suture stitch linking pattern provided by Sequent using No. 0 UHMWPE suture in a continuous “N” configuration contributed to the greater strength and stiffness that it displayed during load-to-failure testing. This pattern provided a load-sharing effect along the entire length of the repair with the 5 suture strands working across 4 PEEK implants functioning as a single construct. Each of the other comparison groups used 4 suture strands across the repair site. Stiffness is an important biomechanical test factor, as it describes the ability of the meniscus repair complex to remain intact, avoiding deformation when loaded. We found that the 4 implant–5 strand Sequent using No. 0 UHMWPE suture in a continuous “N” configuration provided greater repair stiffness than conventional inside-out suturing using 2-0 braided polyester suture and Sequent using No. 0 UHMWPE suture in an interrupted fashion.

Two in vitro biomechanical studies were identified that used a submaximal cyclic loading protocol to evaluate meniscus repair gapping.21,22 Using a micrometer, McDermott et al21 observed 1.9- to 3.4-mm mean gapping in bovine meniscus repair sites in 4 test groups: 2-0 PDS suture, bioabsorbable Meniscus Arrow, Meniscal Fastener, and T-Fix. Using digital calipers and cadaveric menisci, Mehta and Terry22 measured repair gapping using the Meniscal Cinch, Ultra Fast-Fix, and MaxFire (Biomet, Warsaw, Indiana) all-inside meniscus repair devices after 100 and 500 submaximal loading cycles, reporting 4.9- to 7.2-mm gaps after 500 cycles. The benefit of performing gapping measurements in addition to standard biomechanical test measurements is that they are more specific to the integrity of meniscus repair site fixation. In contrast, displacement measurements represent the composite change in distance between 2 fixation clamps over the course of the biomechanical test program. This measurement is influenced by tissue properties, and possible movement at the tissue-clamp interface, in addition to changes at the meniscus lesion repair site. This may be why the gapping measurements that we observed displayed statistically significant differences while displacement did not. This study standardized displacement during submaximal cyclic loading to the mean of the initial 10 loading cycles. Data of gapping during submaximal cyclic loading were standardized to the measurement taken with the specimen clamped under a 5-N (1.1-lb) tensile load before cyclic loading. These controls and standardization steps were taken to improve study consistency, reliability, and validity. We failed to identify significant group displacement differences during submaximal cyclic loading or during load-to-failure testing. We found that the biomechanical test performance of Sequent using No. 0 UHMWPE suture in an interrupted configuration was inferior to Sequent using No. 0 UHMWPE suture in a continuous “N” configuration despite both using the same strong suture material. Despite reduced failure loads, Sequent using No. 0 UHMWPE suture in an interrupted configuration still displayed less gapping than the inside-out repair using 2-0 braided polyester suture.

As with all in vitro biomechanical test models, inherent study strengths and weaknesses exist. Study strengths include use of a standardized surgical method, a biomechanical test protocol, an accepted clamping method, and specific investigator assignments including failure mode reporting by a trained researcher other than the surgeon. We used porcine menisci to ensure consistent tissue quality. Obtaining a similar number of healthy, young cadaveric specimens would have been quite difficult. Porcine menisci have been widely used for in vitro biomechanical testing of meniscus repair devices.5,12,15,18,26,29 We also selected a submaximal cyclic loading protocol, which attempted to simulate loads comparable with what the meniscus repair experiences early after surgery.9,15,34-36 Like all in vitro biomechanical studies, this study only provides time zero information, estimating fixation integrity early after meniscus repair.5 This study does not provide any information regarding tissue biology or the healing timeline of a repaired peripheral meniscus tear. With this study model, we assumed that the groups that withstood higher failure loads, displayed greater stiffness, and had less displacement and less gapping would likely provide the better environment for meniscus repair healing to occur.25

A key study weakness is our use of an in vitro biomechanical model, which applied tensile loads perpendicular to the meniscus repair site (ie, “worst-case scenario testing”). The physiological forces that cause in vivo meniscus tearing are not simply distractive forces but also possess considerable shear and compression forces.26,27 We acknowledge that the use of No. 0 UHMWPE sutures in the Sequent groups compared with the weaker 2-0 braided polyester suture in the inside-out suture group and No. 0 braided polyester suture in the Fast-Fix group likely influenced study results, as this suture displays stronger material properties.4,5 Had we tested a Fast-Fix group using No. 0 UHMWPE sutures, the results we observed may have differed. However, when knee surgeons use an inside-out meniscus repair technique, they commonly rely on braided polyester sutures. Additionally, although suture material properties contribute substantially to ultimate failure load test results, they contribute considerably less to the gapping differences that were observed during submaximal cyclic loading. During submaximal cyclic loading, each all-inside repair method that was studied displayed less gapping, regardless if a No. 0 UHMWPE or braided polyester suture was used, than the group that was repaired using inside-out suturing with 2-0 braided polyester suture.

We acknowledge that different suture configurations may also have influenced biomechanical test results. Use of No. 0 UHMWPE sutures to create a continuous “N” configuration with 1 oblique and 2 vertical suture components is a key feature of Sequent that enables it to function as a single stitch linkage. Each of the all-inside meniscus repair groups had 4 implants deployed. This study has shown that peripheral meniscus lesions repaired with Sequent using No. 0 UHMWPE suture in either a continuous or an interrupted configuration provide time zero biomechanical test characteristics that are at least comparable with meniscus repair using 2-0 braided polyester suture and an inside-out suture technique. The Sequent device using No. 0 UHMWPE suture also performed favorably to Fast-Fix using No. 0 braided polyester suture, a commonly used all-inside meniscus repair device.

Our gapping measurement method provided a valid and reliable 2-dimensional method for evaluating separation at the meniscus repair site. Gapping, however, is a 3-dimensional phenomenon. While this measurement method accurately depicted the maximum distance between the meniscus lesion edges, it did not provide information regarding the presence of any puckering or corrugation at the repair site. Puckering or corrugation at the meniscus repair site is more likely to occur with a combined compression–shear force loading model, however, rather than the tensile loads used in this study. Further in vivo studies using animal models and prospective clinical studies with long-term follow-up are needed to confirm these findings. Information such as this is essential to support the efficacy of surgical interventions designed to preserve the function of a torn meniscus.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Under controlled, standardized surgical and biomechanical test conditions, Sequent using No. 0 UHMWPE suture in a continuous “N” configuration displayed superior load at failure to Fast-Fix using No. 0 braided polyester suture, greater stiffness than an inside-out repair using 2-0 braided polyester suture, and greater resistance to gapping than an inside-out repair using 2-0 braided polyester suture. The suture pulling free from an implant was the primary failure mode for Sequent using No. 0 UHMWPE suture regardless if a continuous “N” or an interrupted configuration was used. Failure load was significantly less for Sequent using No. 0 UHMWPE suture in an interrupted configuration compared with its use in a continuous “N” configuration.

ack.p: The authors thank Dr Steven Arnoczky for his assistance with meniscus clamp acquisition and his continued support and friendship.
